definitions.definition: An elongated piece of wood or similar material, typically put to some use, for example as a wand or baton .

subdefinitions.definition: A small, thin branch from a tree or bush ; a twig ; a branch .
examples: The beaver's dam was made out of sticks .

subdefinitions.definition: A relatively long, thin piece of wood , of any size.
examples: I found several good sticks in the brush heap.
What do you call a boomerang that won't come back? A stick .

subdefinitions.definition: ( US ) A timber board , especially a two by four (inches).
examples: I found enough sticks in dumpsters at construction sites to build my shed.

subdefinitions.definition: A cane or walking stick (usually wooden, metal or plastic) to aid in walking .
examples: I don’t need my stick to walk, but it’s helpful.

subdefinitions.definition: A cudgel or truncheon (usually of wood, metal or plastic), especially one carried by police or guards.
examples: As soon as the fight started, the guards came in swinging their sticks .

subdefinitions.definition: ( carpentry ) The vertical member of a cope-and-stick joint.
( nautical ) A mast or part of a mast of a ship; also , a yard .
( figuratively ) A piece (of furniture , especially if wooden).
examples: We were so poor we didn't have one stick of furniture.

definitions.definition: Any roughly cylindrical (or rectangular) unit of a substance.
examples: Sealing wax is available as a cylindrical or rectangular stick .

subdefinitions.definition: a stick of butter ( chiefly Canada , US ) A small rectangular block, with a length several times its width, which contains by volume one half of a cup of shortening ( butter , margarine or lard ).
examples: The recipe calls for half a stick of butter.

subdefinitions.definition: a stick of gum A standard rectangular strip of chewing gum.
examples: Don’t hog all that gum, give me a stick !

subdefinitions.definition: ( slang ) A cigarette ( usually a tobacco cigarette, less often a marijuana cigarette ) .
examples: Cigarettes are taxed at one dollar per stick .

definitions.definition: Material or objects attached to a stick or the like.

subdefinitions.definition: A bunch of something wrapped around or attached to a stick.
examples: My parents bought us each a stick of cotton candy.

subdefinitions.definition: ( archaic ) A scroll that is rolled around (mounted on, attached to) a stick.

( military ) The structure to which a set of bombs in a bomber aircraft are attached and which drops the bombs when it is released. The bombs themselves and, by extension, any load of similar items dropped in quick succession such as paratroopers or containers.

definitions.definition: A tool, control, or instrument shaped somewhat like a stick.

subdefinitions.definition: ( US , colloquial ) A manual transmission , a vehicle equipped with a manual transmission, so called because of the stick-like, i.e. twig-like, control (the gear shift) with which the driver of such a vehicle controls its transmission . the stick -shift lever in a manual transmission car ( US , colloquial , uncountable ) Vehicles, collectively, equipped with manual transmissions.
examples: I grew up driving a stick , but many people my age didn't.
I grew up driving stick , but many people my age didn't.

subdefinitions.definition: ( aviation ) The control column of an aircraft ; a joystick . ( By convention, a wheel-like control mechanism with a handgrip on opposite sides, similar to the steering wheel of an automobile, can also be called the "stick", although " yoke " or " control wheel " is more commonly seen. )
( aviation , uncountable ) Use of the stick to control the aircraft.
( US military slang , World War I ) An aircraft ’s propeller .
( video games ) A joystick .
( computing ) A memory stick .
( slang ) A handgun .
( dated , letterpress typography ) A composing stick , the tool used by compositors to assemble lines of type.
( jazz , slang ) The clarinet .
two hockey sticks , for the goalie at right a lacrosse stick ( sports , generically ) A long thin implement used to control a ball or puck in sports like hockey , polo , and lacrosse .
examples: Tripping with the stick is a violation of the rules.

subdefinitions.definition: ( horse racing ) The short whip carried by a jockey .
( boardsports ) A board as used in board sports, such as a surfboard , snowboard , or skateboard .
( golf ) The pole bearing a small flag that marks the hole.
examples: His wedge shot bounced off the stick and went in the hole.

subdefinitions.definition: ( US , slang , uncountable ) The cue used in billiards , pool , snooker , etc. The game of pool , or an individual pool game.
examples: His stroke with that two-piece stick is a good as anybody's in the club.
He shoots a mean stick of pool.

subdefinitions.definition: ( golf ) The long-range driving ability of a golf club .
( baseball ) The potential hitting power of a specific bat .
( baseball ) General hitting ability.
( field hockey or ice hockey ) The potential accuracy of a hockey stick, implicating also the player using it.

definitions.definition: ( slang , dated ) A person or group of people. (Perhaps, in some senses, because people are, broadly speaking, tall and thin, like pieces of wood.)

subdefinitions.definition: A thin or wiry person; particularly a flat-chested woman.
( magic ) An assistant planted in the audience.
( gambling ) A shill or house player.
A stiff, stupidly obstinate person.
( military aviation , from joystick ) A fighter pilot.
( military , South Africa ) A small group of (infantry) soldiers .

definitions.definition: Encouragement or punishment, or (resulting) vigour or other improved behavior.

subdefinitions.definition: ( figurative ) A negative stimulus or a punishment . (This sense derives from the metaphor of using a stick, a long piece of wood, to poke or beat a beast of burden to compel it to move forward.)
( slang , uncountable ) Corporal punishment , beatings ; ( figurative ) criticism .
( slang ) Vigor ; spirit ; effort, energy, intensity.
examples: He really gave that digging some stick .
She really gave that bully some stick .
Give it some stick !

subdefinitions.definition: ( slang ) Vigorous driving of a car; gas .
( obsolete ) An English Imperial unit of length equal to 2 inches .
( archaic , rare ) A quantity of eels , usually 25.

definitions.definition: ( computing ) Any of the eight 16- character groups making up the 128 characters of the 7-bit ASCII character set.

main_definition: An elongated piece of wood or similar material, typically put to some use, for example as a wand or baton .
secondary_definitions: Any roughly cylindrical (or rectangular) unit of a substance.
Material or objects attached to a stick or the like.
A tool, control, or instrument shaped somewhat like a stick.
( slang , dated ) A person or group of people. (Perhaps, in some senses, because people are, broadly speaking, tall and thin, like pieces of wood.)
Encouragement or punishment, or (resulting) vigour or other improved behavior.
( computing ) Any of the eight 16- character groups making up the 128 characters of the 7-bit ASCII character set.

definitions.definition: ( uncountable ) The tendency to stick (remain stuck), stickiness .

subdefinitions.definition: ( motor racing ) The traction of tires on the road surface.

definitions.definition: ( uncountable ) That which sticks (remains attached to another surface).

subdefinitions.definition: ( fishing ) The amount of fishing line resting on the water surface before a cast ; line stick .

definitions.definition: ( countable ) A thrust with a pointed instrument; a stab .

main_definition: ( uncountable ) The tendency to stick (remain stuck), stickiness .
secondary_definitions: ( uncountable ) That which sticks (remains attached to another surface).
( countable ) A thrust with a pointed instrument; a stab .

definitions.definition: ( obsolete ) The customary length (according to the material used) of a piece or roll of textile fabrics imported from Flanders .

main_definition: ( obsolete ) The customary length (according to the material used) of a piece or roll of textile fabrics imported from Flanders .
